name: St. Wilfrid
summary: Wilfrid was a bishop who played a key role in the Synod of Whitby (664), where he successfully argued for the adoption of Roman practices over Celtic ones, particularly regarding the date of Easter. He was a strong advocate for Roman authority and practices in England and was known for his missionary work and church building. He faced exile multiple times due to political conflicts.

name: St. Bede the Venerable
summary: Bede, known as the Venerable Bede, was an English monk, scholar, and historian. He is best known for his 'Ecclesiastical History of the English People,' which is a primary source for early English history. He was a prolific writer on theology, history, grammar, and science. He is the only native of Great Britain to be named a Doctor of the Church.

writings.title: Ecclesiastical History of the English People

name: St. Boniface

locations.description: Bishop and missionary, martyred in Frisia

summary: Boniface was an English missionary who is known as the Apostle of Germany. He organized the Church in Germany and reformed the Frankish Church. He founded several monasteries, including Fulda, and was martyred while on a mission to Frisia. He is considered one of the most important figures in the Christianization of Germany.

name: St. John of Damascus
summary: John of Damascus was a Christian monk, priest, and theologian. He is best known for his defense of icons during the Iconoclast Controversy. His work 'Fount of Knowledge' is a comprehensive summary of Christian doctrine. He is considered the last of the Greek Church Fathers and is venerated as a Doctor of the Church in both East and West.

name: St. Willibrord

locations.description: Bishop of Utrecht, missionary to Frisia

summary: Willibrord was an English missionary who is known as the Apostle of the Frisians. He was the first bishop of Utrecht and worked to convert the Frisians to Christianity. He founded several churches and monasteries and is considered one of the most important missionaries of the early Middle Ages.

name: St. Gregory II
summary: Gregory II was Pope from 715 to 731. He is known for his opposition to the iconoclastic policies of the Byzantine Emperor Leo III, which led to tensions between Rome and Constantinople. He supported the missionary work of Boniface in Germany and worked to strengthen the Church in Italy. He is venerated as a saint.

name: St. Gregory III
summary: Gregory III was Pope from 731 to 741. He continued his predecessor's opposition to iconoclasm and convened a synod in Rome that condemned the iconoclastic policies. He strengthened ties with the Frankish kingdom and supported Boniface's missionary work. He is the last pope to be elected by acclamation.

name: St. Zachary
summary: Zachary was Pope from 741 to 752. He is known for his diplomatic skills and for mediating disputes between the Lombards and the Byzantine Empire. He supported the missionary work of Boniface and worked to reform the Frankish Church. He translated the Dialogues of Gregory the Great into Greek.

name: Pope Hadrian I
summary: Hadrian I was Pope from 772 to 795. He is known for his close relationship with Charlemagne, whom he crowned as Patrician of the Romans. He worked with Charlemagne to defend the Papal States and supported the Carolingian Renaissance. He convened the Second Council of Nicaea (787), which restored the veneration of icons.

name: St. Leo III
summary: Leo III was Pope from 795 to 816. He is most famous for crowning Charlemagne as Holy Roman Emperor on Christmas Day, 800, an event that established the relationship between the papacy and the empire. He survived an attack by Roman nobles and was protected by Charlemagne. He worked to strengthen papal authority and reform the Church.
